tit.cmt: 場所と人の両方に使われるので、英訳を記載しました。

sen.j: 自身番（じしんばん）は、江戸時代に江戸や大阪などの町人地で設けられた番所。
sen.e: Jishinban is a bansho (an ancient form of security office) installed in downtown areas in Edo and Osaka during the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 「町人地」は「繁華街」としました。「町人」の定訳はありますが、これにそのままareaなりdistrictをつけると英語として不自然な印象があります。以降の「町人地」も同じ処理をしました。
sen.e: Jishinban is a bansho (an ancient form of security office) installed in downtown areas in Edo and Osaka during the Edo period.
Jishinban is a bansho (an ancient form of security office) installed in downtown areas in Edo and Osaka during the Edo period.

sen.j: 町内警備を主な役割とし、町人によって運営された。
sen.e: Managed by townspeople, jishinban was mainly responsible for local security.
Managed by townspeople, jishinban was mainly responsible for local security.
Managed by townspeople, jishinban was mainly responsible for local security.

sen.j: 自身番の使用した小屋は自身番屋・番屋などと呼ばれた。
sen.e: The house used as jishinban was called jishinban-ya or ban-ya (simple lodging house).

sen.j: 江戸においては町奉行の監督下にあり、町人地の各町ごとに設けられ（町の規模によっては共同で設置）、運営の費用は各町が負担した。
sen.e: In Edo, jishinban, under the supervision of machi-bugyo (town magistrate), were installed in each town in downtown areas (co-managed by several towns in accordance with town size) and the management expenses were paid by each town.

sen.j: 初期には町の地主自身が番屋で警備をしたため、自身番と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Security officers were called jishinban because, in the early days, local landlords themselves were stationed in ban-ya as such (Self [or selves] is translated as "jishin" in Japanese).
sen.cmt: 日本語独特の掛け言葉であり、そのポイントを文字通りに訳するのは不可能です。最後に括弧を設けて補足しました。

sen.j: のちには地主に代わって町内の家主や雇い人が交代で担当している。
sen.e: Later, heads of households and employed guards, in place of landlords, worked by rotation.
Later, heads of households and employed guards, in place of landlords, worked by rotation.

sen.j: 自身番は町内を見回り、不審者がいれば捕らえて奉行所に訴えた。
sen.e: Patrolling the community, jishinban caught suspicious individuals and handed them over to the magistrate's office.

sen.j: また、火の番も重要な役割であり、自身番屋の多くには、屋根に梯子（小規模な火の見櫓）や半鐘が備えられていた。
sen.e: In addition, watching out for fire was jishinban's another main responsibility and many jishinban-ya had their roofs equipped with a ladder (small fire watchtower called hinomi-yagura) and hansho (fire bell).

sen.j: このため、捕り物道具（捕具）や火消道具が番屋内に用意されていた。
sen.e: Arresting and firefighting devices were installed inside ban-ya.

sen.j: 寄合所としても使用され、町内の事務処理も自身番屋で行われた。
sen.e: Jishinban was used as yoriaijo (meeting place) as well, where the community-related matters were handled.

sen.j: 奉行所からの書類受け付けや人別帳管理などがその内容である。
sen.e: Specifically, jishinban received the documents from the magistrate's office or kept ninbetsucho (census registers).
